cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
when did the eagles win the super bowl
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: 
To determine when the Philadelphia Eagles won the Super Bowl, I need to recall the history of the Super Bowl and the Eagles' performance in it. The Eagles have participated in multiple Super Bowls, but they are particularly known for their victory in Super Bowl LII. This game took place on February 4, 2018, where the Eagles defeated the New England Patriots. This victory marked the first Super Bowl win in the franchise's history.

Answer: The Philadelphia Eagles won the Super Bowl on February 4, 2018.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
when did the eagles win the super bowl
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['The Eagles defeated the New England Patriots by a score of 41–33 in Super Bowl LII at U.S. Bank Stadium in Minneapolis, Minnesota on February 4, 2018, ending the alleged curse.\n', "The Eagles went on to win Super Bowl LII, 41–33. It was the team's first NFL championship since 1960, and first ever Super Bowl win.\n", "On January 23, 2005, the Eagles reached a fourth consecutive conference championship game (the first time this happened in the salary cap era of the NFL). At long last, the Eagles justified the hopes of their long-suffering fan base, defeating Michael Vick's much-hyped Atlanta Falcons, 27-10, sending them to their first Super Bowl in 24 years. The victory sent the city of Philadelphia into wild celebrations.\n", 'On February 4, 2018, the Philadelphia Eagles defeated the New England Patriots in Super Bowl LII 41-33 to win their first Super Bowl in team history, and first championship since the 1960 NFL Championship.\n', 'The Eagles have won four league titles. Three of these were won prior to the start of the Super Bowl era (in 1948, 1949, and 1960). The fourth and most recent championship was won in Super Bowl LII.\n', "This alleged curse supposedly prevented the Philadelphia Eagles franchise from winning a Super Bowl game. The origin of this curse dates back to 1960, when the Eagles defeated Vince Lombardi and the Green Bay Packers in the 1960 NFL Championship Game. This would be the only playoff loss in Lombardi's coaching career. Following Lombardi's death in 1970, the league honored his legacy by naming the Super Bowl trophy after him. This renaming, combined with the Eagles inability to win another championship after their 1960 victory, led some Eagles fans to believe the franchise was cursed by Vince Lombardi; that beating Lombardi meant never winning the trophy named after him. During that time, the Eagles accumulated a lot of playoff heartbreak, including 2 Super Bowl losses to the Oakland Raiders and New England Patriots, and 3 consecutive NFC Championship Game losses from 2001-2003. \n", 'On January 11, 2009, the team defeated the defending Super Bowl champion New York Giants 23–11 en route to their sixth NFC Championship Game. In the NFC Championship, the Eagles made a rally, going from down 24–6 at halftime to up 25–24 with three minutes left in the fourth quarter, but they lost to the Arizona Cardinals by a score of 32–25 after quarterback Kurt Warner scored a last minute touchdown.\n', 'BULLET::::- February 4 – The Philadelphia Eagles win their first Super Bowl in franchise history by defeating the New England Patriots, 41-33, in Super Bowl LII, ending a 57-year championship drought.\n', "The Philadelphia Eagles season was the franchise's 49th season in the National Football League, they made the postseason for the fourth straight season (first time in franchise history the Eagles had made the postseason four straight times). The team was coming off a Super Bowl loss to the Oakland Raiders the previous season. Because they made the Super Bowl in 1980, they were picked by many to not only reach the Super Bowl, but to win it as well. The Eagles began the 1981 season with 6 straight wins, their best ever start to a season at the time. The Eagles would win then 3 of their next 5 games to sit at 9-2. They would then lose their next 4 games to slip to 9-6 and were in danger of missing out on the playoffs. The next week, they hammered the Cardinals 38-0 to clinch a playoff berth for the fourth straight season. In the playoffs, they met their arch rivals the Giants. It was New York's first playoff appearance in 18 years. In the game, the Giants would stun the eagles 27-21, ending the Eagles season as well as hopes for a second straight Super Bowl appearance. The Eagles would not make the playoffs again until 1988. They also wouldn't reach the Super Bowl again until 2004.\n", 'The Eagles defeated the New England Patriots by a score of 41–33 in Super Bowl LII for their first Super Bowl victory in franchise history. It was also their fourth NFL Championship, and their first league title since 1960. This was the second time the Eagles and Patriots battled in a Super Bowl; when they met in Super Bowl XXXIX, the Patriots won 24–21. Backup quarterback Nick Foles was named Super Bowl MVP and became the first backup to receive this award since his opponent, Tom Brady, did so in Super Bowl XXXVI 15 years earlier. The Eagles defeated both Super Bowl teams from the previous NFL season (the New England Patriots and the Atlanta Falcons) in the playoffs, the third team to beat both of them this season, after the Carolina Panthers and Miami Dolphins. They also defeated both teams who had beaten them in their only two previous Super Bowl appearances: the Oakland Raiders in the regular season, who beat them in Super Bowl XV, and the Patriots in the Super Bowl, who previously beat them in Super Bowl XXXIX.\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model and provide relevant background knowledge regarding the Philadelphia Eagles' Super Bowl victory, we can focus on several key themes and concepts presented in the passages. Here’s a breakdown of the relevant content and its role:

1. **Super Bowl LII Context**:
   - The Eagles won their first Super Bowl (Super Bowl LII) on February 4, 2018, defeating the New England Patriots 41-33. This victory is significant as it marked the team's first Super Bowl win in franchise history and ended a 57-year championship drought since their last NFL Championship in 1960.
   - **Role**: This context is crucial as it establishes the importance of the event in the Eagles' history and highlights the emotional significance for the fan base.

2. **Historical Significance**:
   - The Eagles had previously lost two Super Bowls (Super Bowl XV to the Oakland Raiders and Super Bowl XXXIX to the New England Patriots) before their victory in Super Bowl LII. This history of playoff heartbreak, including the alleged "curse" associated with their inability to win a Super Bowl, adds depth to the narrative of their eventual triumph.
   - **Role**: Understanding this history provides insight into the cultural and emotional weight of the Eagles' victory, as it was not just a game but a culmination of years of disappointment for fans.

3. **The "Curse"**:
   - The passage discusses an alleged curse that supposedly prevented the Eagles from winning a Super Bowl after their 1960 NFL Championship victory against Vince Lombardi's Packers. This belief among fans adds a layer of folklore to the team's narrative.
   - **Role**: This concept introduces the idea of sports curses, which can influence fan psychology and the narrative surrounding a team's performance over time.

4. **Key Players and MVP**:
   - Backup quarterback Nick Foles was named Super Bowl MVP, becoming the first backup to receive this award since Tom Brady in Super Bowl XXXVI. This highlights the unexpected nature of the victory, as Foles stepped in for the injured starter Carson Wentz.
   - **Role**: This detail emphasizes the theme of resilience and the idea that success can come from unexpected sources, which is a common narrative in sports.

5. **Franchise History**:
   - The Eagles have won four league titles, with three prior to the Super Bowl era (1948, 1949, and 1960). This historical context helps to frame the significance of their Super Bowl win within the broader timeline of the franchise.
   - **Role**: This information provides a comprehensive view of the Eagles' achievements and struggles, allowing for a better understanding of their place in NFL history.

6. **Playoff Journey**:
   - The Eagles defeated both the Atlanta Falcons and the New England Patriots in the playoffs leading up to the Super Bowl, showcasing their ability to overcome previous adversaries.
   - **Role**: This narrative arc of overcoming challenges enhances the story of their Super Bowl victory, illustrating the team's growth and determination.

In summary, the extracted content provides a rich historical and emotional context that enhances the understanding of the Eagles' Super Bowl victory. It highlights the significance of the win, the narrative of overcoming adversity, and the cultural implications of sports fandom, all of which contribute to a deeper appreciation of the event.

2. **Historical Significance**:
   - Prior to this victory, the Eagles had lost two Super Bowls: Super Bowl XV to the Oakland Raiders and Super Bowl XXXIX to the New England Patriots. The Philadelphia Eagles won the Super Bowl on February 4, 2018, in Super Bowl LII, defeating the New England Patriots 41-33. This victory marked the first Super Bowl win in the franchise's history and ended a 57-year championship drought since their last NFL Championship in 1960.

**Expert Discussion on the Philadelphia Eagles' Super Bowl Victory**

**Expert 1: Historical Context Specialist**
The Eagles' victory in Super Bowl LII on February 4, 2018, is significant not only because it marked their first Super Bowl win but also because it ended a 57-year championship drought for the franchise. Prior to this, the Eagles had experienced considerable playoff heartbreak, including two Super Bowl losses in 1980 and 2005. This historical context highlights the emotional weight of their victory, as it was a culmination of decades of struggle and disappointment.

**Expert 2: Sports Performance Analyst**
From a performance perspective, the Eagles' win against the New England Patriots, with a score of 41-33, showcased a remarkable offensive strategy. Backup quarterback Nick Foles, who was named Super Bowl MVP, played a pivotal role in the game. His performance not only exemplified the depth of the Eagles' roster but also underscored the unpredictability of sports, where a backup can rise to the occasion in critical moments. This victory also marked a shift in the narrative surrounding the Eagles, who had previously been seen as perennial underdogs.

**Expert 3: Cultural Impact Scholar**
The cultural implications of the Eagles' Super Bowl win are profound. The victory resonated deeply with the city of Philadelphia, which has a passionate sports culture. The idea of a "curse" that supposedly plagued the franchise since their last championship in 1960 added to the narrative surrounding their win. The celebrations that erupted in Philadelphia following the victory were not just about football; they represented a collective release of frustration and joy for a city that had long awaited this moment.

**Expert 4: Statistical Analyst**
From a statistical standpoint, the Eagles' performance in Super Bowl LII was noteworthy. They became the first team to defeat the Patriots in a Super Bowl since the 2004 season, and their 41 points were the most ever scored by a team in a Super Bowl victory against the Patriots. This highlights not only the effectiveness of their offensive strategy but also the significance of their win in the context of NFL history.

**Points of Agreement:**
All experts agree on the significance of the Eagles' victory in terms of its historical context and emotional impact. They recognize that the win was a pivotal moment for the franchise and the city of Philadelphia. Additionally, there is consensus on the importance of Nick Foles' performance and the strategic execution of the game plan.

**Points of Disagreement:**
While there is agreement on the emotional and cultural significance of the victory, there is some divergence in how much weight to give to the "curse" narrative. Some experts believe it adds a layer of depth to the story, while others argue that focusing on the curse detracts from the team's achievements and the skill demonstrated on the field.

**Synthesis of Insights:**
The Philadelphia Eagles' Super Bowl LII victory is a multifaceted event that encapsulates historical significance, cultural resonance, and sports performance. The win not only marked a turning point for the franchise but also served as a moment of catharsis for a city long associated with sports heartbreak. The performance of Nick Foles and the team's strategic execution underscore the unpredictable nature of sports, while the narrative of the "curse" adds an intriguing layer to the story. Together, these perspectives enrich our understanding of the Eagles' triumph, illustrating how sports can reflect broader societal themes and individual narratives of perseverance and success.

It was New York's first playoff appearance in 18 years. In the game, the Giants would stun the eagles 27-21, ending the Eagles season as well as hopes for a second straight Super Bowl appearance. The Eagles would not make the playoffs again until 1988. They also wouldn't reach the Super Bowl again until 2004.
", 'The Eagles defeated the New England Patriots by a score of 41–33 in Super Bowl LII for their first Super Bowl victory in franchise history. It was also their fourth NFL Championship, and their first league title since 1960. This was the second time the Eagles and Patriots battled in a Super Bowl; when they met in Super Bowl XXXIX, the Patriots won 24–21. Backup quarterback Nick Foles was named Super Bowl MVP and became the first backup to receive this award since his opponent, Tom Brady, did so in Super Bowl XXXVI 15 years earlier. The Eagles defeated both Super Bowl teams from the previous NFL season (the New England Patriots and the Atlanta Falcons) in the playoffs, the third team to beat both of them this season, after the Carolina Panthers and Miami Dolphins. They also defeated both teams who had beaten them in their only two previous Super Bowl appearances: the Oakland Raiders in the regular season, who beat them in Super Bowl XV, and the Patriots in the Super Bowl, who previously beat them in Super Bowl XXXIX.
']

2. **Historical Context**:

   - The Eagles had previously lost two Super Bowls: one to the Oakland Raiders and another to the New England Patriots in Super Bowl XXXIX.

To determine when the Philadelphia Eagles won the Super Bowl, I will analyze the relevant historical context and details surrounding their performance in the Super Bowl. The Eagles are particularly noted for their victory in Super Bowl LII, which took place on February 4, 2018. In this game, they defeated the New England Patriots with a score of 41–33. This victory was significant as it marked the Eagles' first Super Bowl win in franchise history and their first NFL championship since 1960.

The Eagles had a long championship drought of 57 years prior to this win, which adds to the significance of the event. They had previously lost two Super Bowls: one to the Oakland Raiders and another to the New England Patriots in Super Bowl XXXIX. The narrative surrounding the Eagles includes an alleged "curse" that fans believed prevented them from winning a Super Bowl since their last championship in 1960. This cultural belief adds emotional weight to their victory, as it ended a long-standing frustration for the fan base and sparked widespread celebrations in Philadelphia.

By synthesizing this information, I can enhance my understanding of the causal relationships between historical performance, cultural narratives, emotional investment, and individual contributions in sports contexts.

### Answer:
The Philadelphia Eagles won the Super Bowl on February 4, 2018, defeating the New England Patriots 41–33 in Super Bowl LII. This victory marked the first Super Bowl win in the franchise's history and ended a 57-year championship drought.

passages:
The Eagles defeated the New England Patriots by a score of 41–33 in Super Bowl LII at U.S. Bank Stadium in Minneapolis, Minnesota on February 4, 2018, ending the alleged curse.
The Eagles went on to win Super Bowl LII, 41–33. It was the team's first NFL championship since 1960, and first ever Super Bowl win.
On January 23, 2005, the Eagles reached a fourth consecutive conference championship game (the first time this happened in the salary cap era of the NFL). At long last, the Eagles justified the hopes of their long-suffering fan base, defeating Michael Vick's much-hyped Atlanta Falcons, 27-10, sending them to their first Super Bowl in 24 years. The victory sent the city of Philadelphia into wild celebrations.
On February 4, 2018, the Philadelphia Eagles defeated the New England Patriots in Super Bowl LII 41-33 to win their first Super Bowl in team history, and first championship since the 1960 NFL Championship.
The Eagles have won four league titles. Three of these were won prior to the start of the Super Bowl era (in 1948, 1949, and 1960). The fourth and most recent championship was won in Super Bowl LII.
This alleged curse supposedly prevented the Philadelphia Eagles franchise from winning a Super Bowl game. The origin of this curse dates back to 1960, when the Eagles defeated Vince Lombardi and the Green Bay Packers in the 1960 NFL Championship Game. This would be the only playoff loss in Lombardi's coaching career. Following Lombardi's death in 1970, the league honored his legacy by naming the Super Bowl trophy after him. This renaming, combined with the Eagles inability to win another championship after their 1960 victory, led some Eagles fans to believe the franchise was cursed by Vince Lombardi; that beating Lombardi meant never winning the trophy named after him. During that time, the Eagles accumulated a lot of playoff heartbreak, including 2 Super Bowl losses to the Oakland Raiders and New England Patriots, and 3 consecutive NFC Championship Game losses from 2001-2003. 
On January 11, 2009, the team defeated the defending Super Bowl champion New York Giants 23–11 en route to their sixth NFC Championship Game. In the NFC Championship, the Eagles made a rally, going from down 24–6 at halftime to up 25–24 with three minutes left in the fourth quarter, but they lost to the Arizona Cardinals by a score of 32–25 after quarterback Kurt Warner scored a last minute touchdown.

The Philadelphia Eagles season was the franchise's 49th season in the National Football League, they made the postseason for the fourth straight season (first time in franchise history the Eagles had made the postseason four straight times).
